instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight but boost is present
threads.message: I have an another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight, but I have 40V one side of <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> and 8.5V on the other. does this mean it is not seeing the screen??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight but boost is present
threads.message: Good chance that is a bad LCD or cable. Try another assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight but boost is present
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight but boost is present
threads.message: tried another assembly still no backlight

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight but boost is present
threads.message: 40v means it is not seeing the screen. I bet the connector is bad, OR, the voltage is not making its way to the connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight but boost is present
threads.message:
You should see 25-27v on a working air backlight circuit at the end. 

You see 40v at <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>, but what do you see right on pins 3 and 4 of the LCD connector?

If you have 40v at pins 3/4 of the LCD connector, the connector is probably broken internally and not sending that to the screen.
